frontmatter.title: Earth System Science Open Challenge 1: L. Jessel, S. Hezzi, M. Roussel
frontmatter.subject: Notebook examples

children.value: This concise notebook demonstrates guidelines for submission of your projects developed under the
Please use this notebook as a template for delivering your workflow with the code you used to produce the results!
For more information, refer to Open Challenge website:
Author(s): Lucas Jessel, Sabrine Hezzi, Marie-Laure Roussel
Challenge: 1 - “Cevenols episodes” or rainfall extreme events in the South-East of France

Mediterranean events of intense rainfall can happen in late summer or in fall in the south-east of France (Cevennes, Rhone valley, Roussillon, Provence) due to warm and humid air coming from the heated sea, thanks to south-east flux mainly driven by any disturbance on France. It causes thunderstorms and heavy precipitation because of the cold air in altitude (that is explained in this region because of the topography : Massif Central, Alpes, Pyrenees). Flooding, runoff and landslides are the most important consequences of these events, due to blocked rainfall in the area.
Monitoring this kind of extreme event is a massive challenge for weather forecasts models, that is why observations from space are a really great tool to help in that way.

In this study, the objective is to use observations products from space to try to detect massive rainfall events and evaluate the accuracy of the results in terms of caracteristics of the precipitation event (daily maximum value and location).
Brocca et al. 2014. Soil as a natural rain gauge: Estimating global rainfall from satellite soil moisture data,
Huffman et al. 2001. Global Precipitation at One-Degree Daily Resolution from Multisatellite Observations,

Among the two observational datasets compared to ERA5 reanalyses, which we have taken as a reference, it emerges as a conclusion that the GPM-CPC product provides a more accurate and faithful representation of an extreme Cevenol precipitation event, such as the one studied, both for the location and the value of the maximum of precipitation.
On the contrary, the GPCP product appears to produce too little precipitation for a Mediterranean episode day and fails to reproduce the maximum precipitation at the correct location.
A more in-depth analysis could be considered to account for differences in spatial resolution between the datasets, as well as to study different days over a longer period of time.

Mediterranean episodes can be dangerous for the population due to their significant and difficult-to-predict consequences such as floods and landslides. Numerous damages need to be considered during these sometimes dramatic events.
This notebook runs with the python environment

import xcube
from xcube.core.store import find_data_store_extensions
from xcube.core.store import get_data_store_params_schema
from xcube.core.store import new_data_store

import boto3
from botocore.exceptions import NoCredentialsError

import os
import shapely.geometry
from IPython.display import JSON
import numpy as np
import xarray as xr

# for the plots
from cartopy import crs as ccrs, feature as cfeature
projPC = ccrs.PlateCarree(central_longitude=0)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.colors as mcolors
import matplotlib.ticker as ticker
%matplotlib inline
plt.rcParams["figure.figsize"] = 16,8

# PUBLIC STORE : for GPM-CPC dataset in the hydrology cube
public_store = new_data_store("s3", root="deep-esdl-public", storage_options=dict(anon=True))

# USER/TEAM STORE : for GPCP and ERA5 datasets in the "homemade" cubes
S3_USER_STORAGE_KEY = os.environ["S3_USER_STORAGE_KEY"]
S3_USER_STORAGE_SECRET = os.environ["S3_USER_STORAGE_SECRET"]
S3_USER_STORAGE_BUCKET = os.environ["endpoint"]
user_store = new_data_store("s3", max_depth=3, root=S3_USER_STORAGE_BUCKET,storage_options=dict(anon=False, key=S3_USER_STORAGE_KEY,secret=S3_USER_STORAGE_SECRET))
Extracting GPM-CPC SM2RAIN ASCAT Dataset (from hydrology cube)

# defining some coordinates inside the region of interest

lat2=45 ; lon2=7
lat3=43 ; lon3=3
lat4=44 ; lon4=7
lat5=44 ; lon5=4
lat6=44 ; lon6=5
lat7=44 ; lon7=6
lat8=44 ; lon8=3

# selecting local precipitation data

precip_point1 = precip_data_hydro.sel(lat=lat1, lon=lon1, method='nearest')
precip_point2 = precip_data_hydro.sel(lat=lat2, lon=lon2, method='nearest')
precip_point3 = precip_data_hydro.sel(lat=lat3, lon=lon3, method='nearest')
precip_point4 = precip_data_hydro.sel(lat=lat4, lon=lon4, method='nearest')
precip_point5 = precip_data_hydro.sel(lat=lat5, lon=lon5, method='nearest')
precip_point6 = precip_data_hydro.sel(lat=lat6, lon=lon6, method='nearest')
precip_point7 = precip_data_hydro.sel(lat=lat7, lon=lon7, method='nearest')
precip_point8 = precip_data_hydro.sel(lat=lat8, lon=lon8, method='nearest')

plt.figure(figsize=(20, 6))
precip_point1.plot(marker='o', linestyle='-',color='blue')
precip_point2.plot(marker='o', linestyle='-',color='red')
precip_point3.plot(marker='o', linestyle='-',color='green')
precip_point4.plot(marker='o', linestyle='-',color='yellow')
precip_point5.plot(marker='o', linestyle='-',color='purple')
precip_point6.plot(marker='o', linestyle='-',color='cyan')
precip_point7.plot(marker='o', linestyle='-',color='magenta')
precip_point8.plot(marker='o', linestyle='-',color='orange')
plt.xlabel('Day')
plt.ylabel('Daily rainfall (mm/d)')
plt.title('Precipitation from GPM-CPC SM2RAIN-ASCAT (hydrology cube)')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

children.value: 9.3) Searching the maximum values at each grid point for the whole time-serie

children.label: 9.3) Searching the maximum values at each grid point for the whole time-serie

children.value: 9.3.1) compute the maximum values on the region during the whole time-serie for each grid cell

children.label: 9.3.1) compute the maximum values on the region during the whole time-serie for each grid cell

children.value:
hydro_region_precip_max = hydro_region_precip.max(dim = ['time'])

gpcp_region_precip_max = gpcp_cube['precip'].max(dim = ['time'])

era_region_precip_max = era_region_precip.max(dim = ['time'])
9.3.2) Searching the days of massive precip events

children.label: 9.3.2) Searching the days of massive precip events

children.value:
# defining the threshold matrix (maximum values to consider extreme events) 
# applying to datasets to find dates (where the daily precip > threshold)

hydro_threshold = 0.99 * hydro_region_precip_max  
hydro_dates_sup_threshold = hydro_region_precip['time'].where(hydro_region_precip >= hydro_threshold)
hydro_tt = hydro_dates_sup_threshold.dropna(dim='time', how='all')

gpcp_threshold = 0.99 * gpcp_region_precip_max  
gpcp_dates_sup_threshold = gpcp_region_precip['time'].where(gpcp_cube['precip'] >= gpcp_threshold)
gpcp_tt = gpcp_dates_sup_threshold.dropna(dim='time', how='all')

era_threshold = 0.99 * era_region_precip_max 
era_dates_sup_threshold = era_region_precip['time'].where(era_cube['tp'] >= era_threshold)
era_tt = era_dates_sup_threshold.dropna(dim='time', how='all')

children.value: >>> We select the 2nd of october 2020 (detected by GPM-CPC and GPCP)

children.label: >>> We select the 2nd of october 2020 (detected by GPM-CPC and GPCP)

children.value: 9.4) Maps of the daily precipitation for the three datasets on that particular day

children.label: 9.4) Maps of the daily precipitation for the three datasets on that particular day

children.value:
hydro_xtrem_precip_20201002 = hydro_cube['precip'].sel(time='2020-10-02') 

fig = plt.figure()
ax = plt.axes(projection = projPC)
im = ax.pcolormesh(hydro_xtrem_precip_20201002.lon, hydro_xtrem_precip_20201002.lat, hydro_xtrem_precip_20201002.values)
ax.set_extent([lonm, lonM, latm, latM], crs=projPC)
gl = ax.gridlines(draw_labels=True, linewidth=0, alpha=0.5)

ax.coastlines()          
ax.add_feature(cfeature.LAND)
ax.add_feature(cfeature.COASTLINE)
ax.add_feature(cfeature.LAKES, alpha=0.5)
ax.add_feature(cfeature.RIVERS)
cbar = plt.colorbar(im, label='precipitation (mm/d)',  extend='max', anchor=(0.2, 0.5), shrink=0.6, aspect=20)  # ajout de la colorbar
ax.set_title('Total precipitation (mm) on the south-east of France on the 02/10/2020 - from GPM-CPC dataset')

gpcp_xtrem_precip_20201002 = gpcp_region_precip.sel(time='2020-10-02', latitude=slice(latm,latM)) 

# Define a normalization instance for the colorbar (not used here)
norm1 = mcolors.TwoSlopeNorm(vmin=0, vcenter=131.45/2, vmax=131.45)

fig = plt.figure()
ax = plt.axes(projection = projPC)
im = ax.pcolormesh(gpcp_xtrem_precip_20201002.longitude, gpcp_xtrem_precip_20201002.latitude, gpcp_xtrem_precip_20201002.values)#, norm=norm1)
ax.set_extent([lonm, lonM, latm, latM], crs=projPC)
gl = ax.gridlines(draw_labels=True, linewidth=0, alpha=0.5)

ax.coastlines()          
ax.add_feature(cfeature.LAND)
ax.add_feature(cfeature.COASTLINE)
ax.add_feature(cfeature.LAKES, alpha=0.5)
ax.add_feature(cfeature.RIVERS)
cbar = plt.colorbar(im, label='precipitation (mm/d)',  extend='max', anchor=(0.2, 0.5), shrink=0.6, aspect=20) 
ax.set_title('Total precipitation (mm) on the south-east of France on the 02/10/2020 - from GPCP dataset')

era_xtrem_precip_20201002 = 3600.*era_region_precip.sel(time='2020-10-02')[0] 

# Define a normalization instance for the colorbar (not used here)
norm2 = mcolors.TwoSlopeNorm(vmin=0, vcenter=131.45/2, vmax=131.45)

fig = plt.figure()
ax = plt.axes(projection = projPC)
im = ax.pcolormesh(era_xtrem_precip_20201002.longitude, era_xtrem_precip_20201002.latitude, era_xtrem_precip_20201002.values)#, norm=norm2)
ax.set_extent([lonm, lonM, latm, latM], crs=projPC)
gl = ax.gridlines(draw_labels=True, linewidth=0, alpha=0.5)

ax.coastlines()          
ax.add_feature(cfeature.LAND)
ax.add_feature(cfeature.COASTLINE)
ax.add_feature(cfeature.LAKES, alpha=0.5)
ax.add_feature(cfeature.RIVERS)
cbar = plt.colorbar(im, label='precipitation (mm/d)',  extend='max', anchor=(0.2, 0.5), shrink=0.6, aspect=20)  # ajout de la colorbar
ax.set_title('Total precipitation (mm) on the south-east of France on the 02/10/2020 - from ERA5 dataset')

# maximum value and index of latitude and longitude of the maximum

print('FOR GPM-CPC')
print('maximum value: (mm/d)', np.nanmax(hydro_xtrem_precip_20201002))
print('index for latitude and longitude of the maximum: ', np.where(hydro_xtrem_precip_20201002 == np.nanmax(hydro_xtrem_precip_20201002)))
hydro_xtrem_precip_20201002.isel(lat=446, lon=1487)

    color_value_min:        0

children.value:
### time serie around the 2nd of october 2020, at the grid cell of the maximum value

lat_hydro=44.16 ; lon_hydro=7.687

precip_point_hydro = precip_data_hydro.sel(lat=lat_hydro, lon=lon_hydro, method='nearest')
precip_point_hydro1 = precip_point_hydro.sel(time=slice('2020-09-30', '2020-10-06'))

plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4))
plt.bar(precip_point_hydro1.time.values, precip_point_hydro1.values, width=0.1, color='blue', align='center')
plt.title('Precipitation from GPM CPC SM2RAIN-ASCAT (hydrology cube)')
plt.xlabel('Day')
plt.ylabel('Daily rainfall (mm/d)')
plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha='right')
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# maximum value and index of latitude and longitude of the maximum

print('FOR GPCP')
print('maximum value: (mm/d)', np.nanmax(gpcp_xtrem_precip_20201002))
print('index for latitude and longitude of the maximum: ', np.where(gpcp_xtrem_precip_20201002 == np.nanmax(gpcp_xtrem_precip_20201002)))

gpcp_xtrem_precip_20201002.isel(latitude=2, longitude=5)

precip_point_era1 = precip_point_era.sel(time=slice('2020-09-30', '2020-10-06'))

plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4))
